Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Development of a Novel Process for the Manufacture of Iodine-131 for Medical Use
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Phase I Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to provide a domestic manufacturing source of the critical medical isotope Iodine-131 (I-131). I-131 is the primary therapeutic for several malignancies and is a key element of several new cancer treatment medicines. Despite its highly attractive features, manufacturing a high-specific activity I-131 product in conformance with strict pharmacopeial requirements is extremely challenging; the high specific activity product is only made by fissioning actinides, such as uranium. This route, although more complicated than the neutron irradiation of tellurium, produces a more favorable product in terms of ease of use and efficacy. SHINE Medical Technologies, Inc. is working on a highly innovative, fissioning technology for manufacturing manufacture several important medical isotopes here in the U.S. Due to the transitory nature of medical isotopes, they have no meaningful shelf life and cannot be stockpiled. Having a domestic supplier is critical to supply and logistics issues. Alleviating such supply concerns will considerably reduce the health risk to patients who rely on these beneficial healthcare products. With manufacturing located in the U.S., SHINE could create a number of high-technology, well-paying jobs for the economy of Wisconsin.

The objectives of this Phase I research project are to better understand and, thus, control the oxidation state of iodine in an aqueous homogeneous nuclear irradiation vessel so that it may be extracted and purified for medical use. Iodine has a rich chemistry, particularly in an aqueous system and which is subjected to considerable irradiation by alpha, beta, gamma and x radiation. Without controlling its oxidation state, we cannot control its chemical speciation and, therefore, its extraction and purification from the irradiated aqueous solution. Extraction of the radioiodine is greatly complicated by the need to preserve efforts to extract the more valuable Mo-99 and eliminate impact on other safety and environmental concerns of the chemical plant (corrosion control, waste management, etc.) Accomplishing these goals will allow SHINE to become a domestic manufacturer of I-131 (as well as other medical isotopes) relieving supply issues and risks for patients and healthcare providers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aim 1.  Control the oxidation state of the iodine species generated by the fission of U-235 in the SHINE manufacturing process.

Aim 2.  Extract the iodine from surrogate SHINE solutions using solid phase extraction media.

We found that the four predominate forms of iodine in the SHINE target solution can all be reduced to iodide, the chemical form with the most commerical value.

Sodium metabisulfite and sodium thiosulfate are both effective at the pH of our system at fully reducing the iodine species to iodide and in a timeframe that is commericially useful.

Anion exchange media are effective at extracting the iodide from aqueous solution, but most will not release the iodide in a manner that is suitable for commerical application with the exception of one particular resin from DOW.  The resin can be regenerated for multiple uses, at least in the non-irradiated experiments of Phase I.

Additionally, copper metal and platinum metals are effective at "polishing" the iodide after stripping from the ion exchange resin.  The copper would be the more economical choice, but the platinum can also be in a form where it is a coating on a copper granule, bringing the cost down.  The metals can be regenerated for multiple use.


Last Modified: 04/01/2016
Modified by: Jeff Driscoll
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Aim 1. Control the oxidation state of the iodine species generated by the fission of U-235 in the SHINE manufacturing process. Aim 2. Extract the iodine from surrogate SHINE solutions using solid phase extraction media. We found that the four predominate forms of iodine in the SHINE target solution can all be reduced to iodide, the chemical form with the most commerical value. Sodium metabisulfite and sodium thiosulfate are both effective at the pH of our system at fully reducing the iodine species to iodide and in a timeframe that is commericially useful. Anion exchange media are effective at extracting the iodide from aqueous solution, but most will not release the iodide in a manner that is suitable for commerical application with the exception of one particular resin from DOW. The resin can be regenerated for multiple uses, at least in the non-irradiated experiments of Phase I. Additionally, copper metal and platinum metals are effective at "polishing" the iodide after stripping from the ion exchange resin. The copper would be the more economical choice, but the platinum can also be in a form where it is a coating on a copper granule, bringing the cost down. The metals can be regenerated for multiple use. Last Modified: 04/01/2016 Submitted by: Jeff Driscoll
